oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Grant Street as seen from the William Penn Hotel with a view of the First English Evangelical Lutheran Church. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: History of 843 Western Avenue
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Peterson, Carol (author,) (researcher.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: North Side (Pittsburgh, Pa.)--Buildings, structures, etc
North Side (Pittsburgh, Pa.)--History
Buildings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Contains a detailed review of the history, age, and ownership of 843 Western Avenue, in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. The home was constructed no later than 1860, and probably as early as about 1850. The house was designed in a transitional architectural style that incorporated elements of the Greek Revival and Italianate styles. The Irwin family, who owned property on Western Avenue between Brighton Road and Allegheny Avenue, was responsible for the construction of the building. The Irwin family then lived in a mansion facing Brighton Road, and never occupied 843 Western Avenue. In 1860, the Irwin family sold the building to George Elliot, who used it as a rental property. His tenants included the family of Benjamin Oppenheimer, a merchant tailor. The building has now had a total of 17 owners.
History of 843 Western Avenue -- Age of 843 Western Avenue -- Ownership -- The Irwin family and the rope walk -- George Elliott; early occupants -- Supplementary materials.
researched and written by Carol J. Peterson.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Indian Trail Steps
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Pittsburgh City Photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Duquesne Heights (Pittsburgh, Pa.)
Stairs--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh.
Housing--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh.
Indian Trail Steps (Pittsburgh, Pa.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A general view of the Duquesne Heights steps leading to Shaler Street, looking west. These steps led travelers from the South Side, near the Pittsburgh and Lake Erie Railroad Station, to Mount Washington. The half-mile rise of steps climbing the treacherous side of the hill is presumed to trace an old Native American trail. These stairs ceased to exist in usable form by the late 1930s.
Shaler Street

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hump District Construction
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Pittsburgh City Photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Streets--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh--Maintenance and repair.
Blue collar workers--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh.
Pedestrians--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh.
Commercial buildings--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh.
Horse-drawn vehicles--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh.
Fifth Avenue (Pittsburgh, Pa.).
Downtown (Pittsburgh, Pa.).
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A view of Hump District construction on Fifth Avenue from Grant Street to Smithfield Street. During the 1900s, the "hump" cut took place in the area of Downtown known as Grant's Hill. The project began with planning in 1909 and ended with the final cut in 1913. It changed the gradient of Grant Street, Diamond Street, and Oliver, Fifth, Sixth, Webster and Wylie Avenues. Please see, Frederick Law Olmstead, Pittsburgh Main Thoroughfares and the Down Town District: http://digital.library.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/t/text/text-idx?c=pitttext&view=toc&idno=00aep1324m for more information.
Fifth Avenue

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rock Concert at Schenley Park
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Pittsburgh City Photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Oakland (Pittsburgh, Pa.).
Schenley Park (Pittsburgh, Pa.).
Concerts--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A view of a rock concert at Schenley Park. Schenley Park dates back to 1889 when Mary Croghan Schenley donated 300 acres to the City of Pittsburgh for a park. Officials purchased over 100 additional acres from her, bringing the total acreage to 456. The park was inspired by Fredrick Law Olmstead's work and the work of other landscape architects of the time. Plantings were laid out in 1896 by Scottish botanist William Falconer. Interestingly, in 1774 the price for one acre in the area now known as Schenley Park was $1.21. In 2005 dollars, that is a value of $13.12 per acre.
Schenley Park

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Herr's Island Bridge. This bridge is one of the oldest surviving river bridges in the area and is now used for pedestrian traffic on the Three Rivers Heritage Trail. Herr's Island was renamed Washington's Landing when the City of Pittsburgh removed industrial waste left by a century of stockyards, meat-packing plants, warehouses, and oil refineries making the island habitable.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pittsburgh City Photographer collection, 1901-2002
Collection of the Pittsburgh City Photographer, 1901-2002
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Public works--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh--Photographs
Streets--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh--Design and construction--Photographs
Bridges--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh--Design and construction--Photographs
Tunnels--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh--Design and construction--Photographs
Parks--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh--Photographs
Neighborhood--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh--Photographs
Business enterprises--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh--Photographs
Buildings--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh--Photographs
Dwellings--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh--Photographs
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The collection is comprised entirely of photographic prints and negatives and does not contain the office records for the Pittsburgh City Photographer save a few copies relating to supply purchases and the number of photographs created for a few years prior to 1910, This information is also found in the city's annual report. The real record of the duties of the photographers can be found within the photographs that comprise the Pittsburgh City Photographer Collection. The Collection of the Pittsburgh City Photographer contains film negatives, glass plate negatives, and photographic prints as commissioned from the Department of Public Works, Division of Photography, City of Pittsburgh by other city departments. The dates covered by this collection are 1901, 1905, and 1907-2002. The city photographers' tasks included, but were not limited to, documenting construction of roads, bridges, sewers, and other public works projects in the city of Pittsburgh. They also photographed the rebuilding of city streets, improvement of the water supply infrastructure, mayoral events, and accidents involving city vehicles. Some specific examples are the 1905 construction of the filtered water reservoir, the 1911 North Side flood district survey, and the 1912 excavation of the "Hump". The engineering photographs are taken from different compass points, at different times, and at various sites, showing a definitive picture of a particular neighborhood at a particular time. There are also negatives of printed materials including mayor's correspondence, speeches and editorial cartoons drawn by Cy Hungerford regarding the mayor, Charles Kline, circa 1927. The collection is arranged chronologically by year and sequentially by image number. Early city photographers used view cameras in the course of their work. Negatives in the collection range from modern 35mm to 8x10 glass plate with the most common sizes being 5x7 inches and 6.5 x 8.5 inches. Glass plate negatives were used until the mid 1920s when the photographers made the move to flexible sheet film. Negative sizes in the collection reflect photographic trends of the time in which they were created. Nearly all negatives are meticulously identified. Glass plate negatives have labels hand-stamped on the emulsion side. Sheet film labels were typed onto tissue paper and then pasted onto the emulsion side. The labels contained the following information: 1. An abbreviation for the department of bureau for which the image was made; 2. A brief description of the image; 3. The date the exposure was made; 4. An individual image number. The collection is arranged chronologically by year and sequentially by image number assigned by the photographer. A database containing a searchable itemized and catalogued inventory of individual photographic images is available up to 1938 and from 1954 to 1958 to locate photographs from a specific period, event, street, or neighborhood. Some photographs appear online as part of the Historic Pittsburgh Image Collections and can be found at http://images.library.pitt.edu/c/cp
Pittsburgh City Photographer Collection, AIS.1971.05, Archives Service Center, University of Pittsburgh.
Digital reproductions of selected images in the collection are available electronically at
Gift of Joe Mueller, Chief Photographer, City-County Building, in 1971 and 1972. Additional items were donated by of George Coppola, Photography Unit Department of Public Safety, in April 2003.

The earliest known city photographer was Brady W. Stewart, whose name can found stamped on envelopes that contained some of the earliest negatives. Stewart eventually set up his own photography studio which operated under his name in downtown Pittsburgh. Other city photographers included Emil Kloes, who worked in the 1920s and 1930s; Luke James, who worked in the 1930s; and Joseph Mueller, who worked from the 1950s to the 1970s. The position of City Photographer was transferred to the Department of Public Safety from the Department of Public Works in the early 1970s.

Finding aid Available in repository and on Internet; Folder level control; http://digital.library.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/f/findaid/findaid-idx?type=simple;c=ascead;view=text;subview=outline;didno=US-PPiU-ais197105

Pittsburgh (Pa.) Department of Public Safety. Photo Unit.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A view of the Hump District on Fifth Avenue at Wylie Avenue. During the 1900s, the "hump" cut took place in the area of Downtown known as Grant's Hill. The project began with planning in 1909 and ended with the final cut in 1913. It changed the gradient of Grant Street, Diamond Street, and Oliver, Fifth, Sixth, Webster and Wylie Avenues. Please see, Frederick Law Olmstead, Pittsburgh Main Thoroughfares and the Down Town District: http://digital.library.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/t/text/text-idx?c=pitttext&view=toc&idno=00aep1324m for more information.

It changed the gradient of Grant Street, Diamond Street, and Oliver, Fifth, Sixth, Webster and Wylie Avenues. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mayor Charles H. Kline
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Pittsburgh City Photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 414 Grant Street

Mayor Charles H. Kline (front left) in a group photo with City County Building office employees on the day of his resignation. Mayor Kline's second term would run short as Mayor Kline and a supplies department head would be charged with 43 counts of misfeasance and malfeasance in office in 1931, according to his Pennsylvania State Senate short biography. Mayor Kline was convicted with the charges in 1932. though he would appeal for the next year before dying in July, 1933 due to declining health. His term would be finished by John S. Herron. Mayor Herron is the last Republic mayor of Pittsburgh to date.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: History of 835 North Lincoln Avenue
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Peterson, Carol (author,) (researcher.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: North Side (Pittsburgh, Pa.)--Buildings, structures, etc
North Side (Pittsburgh, Pa.)--History
Buildings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Contains a detailed review of the history, age, and ownership of 835 North Lincoln Avenue, in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. John Frazier, a partner in a prominent Allegheny City contracting firm, constructed the building between 1864 and 1867. The house was sold to Mark W. Watson in 1875. During the 1910's the building was converted into an apartment building by the Watson family.
History of 835 North Lincoln Avenue -- Age of 835 North Lincoln Avenue -- John and Eleanor Frazier -- Mark W. and Margareta A. Watson, Harriet Watson -- Occupants in 1920 -- Supplementary materials.
Researched and written by Carol J. Peterson.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Grant Street, with the Allegheny County Courthouse and Jail on the right, during the Hump District's "hump" removal. In the 1900s, the "hump" cut took place in the downtown area known as Grant's Hill. The project began with planning in 1909 and ended with the final cut in 1913. It changed the gradient of Grant Street, Diamond Street, and Oliver, Fifth, Sixth, Webster and Wylie Avenues. For more information, please see Frederick Law Olmstead, Pittsburgh Main Thoroughfares and the Down Town District: http://digital.library.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/t/text/text-idx?c=pitttext&view=toc&idno=00aep1324m

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Streets--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh--Maintenance and repair.
Commercial buildings--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh.
Dwellings--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh.
Dante Alley (Pittsburgh, Pa.).
Downtown (Pittsburgh, Pa.).
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hump cut progress view of Dante Alley at Sixth Avenue looking to Tunnel Street. The "hump" cut took place in the area of Downtown known as Grant's Hill. The project began with planning in 1909 and ended with the final cut in 1913. It changed the gradient of Grant Street, Diamond Street, and Oliver, Fifth, Sixth, Webster and Wylie Avenues. Please see, Frederick Law Olmstead, Pittsburgh Main Thoroughfares and the Down Town District: http://digital.library.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/t/text/text-idx?c=pitttext&view=toc&idno=00aep1324m for more information.
Dante Alley

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Pittsburgh City Photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Streets--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh--Maintenance and repair.

Fifth Avenue (Pittsburgh, Pa.).
Downtown (Pittsburgh, Pa.).
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A view of the Hump District on Fifth Avenue from Sixth Avenue to Ross Street. During the 1900s, the "hump" cut took place in the area of Downtown known as Grant's Hill. The project began with planning in 1909 and ended with the final cut in 1913. It changed the gradient of Grant Street, Diamond Street, and Oliver, Fifth, Sixth, Webster and Wylie Avenues. Please see, Frederick Law Olmstead, Pittsburgh Main Thoroughfares and the Down Town District: http://digital.library.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/t/text/text-idx?c=pitttext&view=toc&idno=00aep1324m for more information.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Streets--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh--Maintenance and repair.

Cherry Way (Pittsburgh, Pa.).
Oliver Avenue (Pittsburgh, Pa.).
Downtown (Pittsburgh, Pa.).
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A view of Cherry Way looking northwest from Oliver Avenue during the hump removal project. Part of the Trinity Episcopal Church is visible. The "hump" cut took place in the downtown area known as Grant's Hill. The project began with planning in 1909 and ended with the final cut in 1913. It changed the gradient of Grant Street, Diamond Street, and Oliver, Fifth, Sixth, Webster and Wylie Avenues. Please see Frederick Law Olmstead, Pittsburgh Main Thoroughfares and the Down Town District: http://digital.library.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/t/text/text-idx?c=pitttext&view=toc&idno=00aep1324m for more information.
Cherry Way

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hump cut progress along the south side of Wylie Avenue looking east from Fifth Avenue. Businesses include the Hotel Sutton. The "hump" cut took place in the downtown area known as Grant's Hill. The project began with planning in 1909 and ended with the final cut in 1913. It changed the gradient of Grant Street, Diamond Street, and Oliver, Fifth, Sixth, Webster and Wylie Avenues. Please see Frederick Law Olmstead, Pittsburgh Main Thoroughfares and the Down Town District: http://digital.library.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/t/text/text-idx?c=pitttext&view=toc&idno=00aep1324m for more information.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Aerial View of Oakland
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Pittsburgh City Photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Oakland (Pittsburgh, Pa.)
Aerial views--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh.
Stadiums--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh.
University of Pittsburgh.
Cathedral of Learning (Pittsburgh, Pa.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An aerial view of Oakland and parts of Shadyside and Squirrel Hill taken for the Civic Center Planning Commission. The view features core Oakland buildings, many belonging to the University of Pittsburgh. The Pitt buildings include Pitt Stadium, Alumni Hall Pennsylvania Hall, Mineral Industries, State Hall (where the Chevron Building is now located), Thaw Hall. Allen Hall (formerly known as the Mellon Institute) and Eberly Hall (the long building in the middle of the image was formerly known Alumni Hall), the Cathedral of Learning, and Heinz Chapel. Other buildings shown include the Soldiers and Sailor Memorial Hall, Forbes Field, the Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh, the Syria Mosque, the Masonic Temple, the Hotel Schenley, and the Mellon Institute and Carnegie Mellon University, then Carnegie Tech.
Unknown

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Typhoid Cases, 1927
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Pittsburgh City Photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Typhoid fever--Mortality--Charts, diagrams, etc.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Chart of Typhoid Death Rates, Worldwide, 1927. The threat of Typhoid was very real for major metropolitain areas such as Pittsburgh. Pittsburgh had the highest death rate from Typhoid between 1893 and 1907. For an in-depth analysis of Pittsburgh and its water system, please see Joel A. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: View taken on Spring Way near the rear entrance to Art's Garage looking to the the 330,000-square-foot Federal Cold Storage building. It later served as storage for Robert Wholey & Co., a fish retailer and wholesaler.

Boats--Pennsylvania--Pittsburgh.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A view of the Port of Pittsburgh in the early 1890s. Boats of all sorts are tied to anchor along the Water Street Wharf. Beginning in the 1800s, Water Street and the Monongahela Wharf combined to be the landing point for commerce and trade. Water Street, which ran above the slopes of the wharf, was full of warehouses and office buildings.
Water Street
